title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing number of artists as 24 and/or does not explain that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.
The response identifies the profit-maximizing number of artists as 24 and explains that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the wage the firm will pay as $16 and/or does not explain that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

The response identifies the wage the firm will pay as $16 and explains that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that there will be a shortage at a wage of $10, does not calculate the shortage as 48 artists, and/or does not show the work.

The response states that there will be a shortage at a wage of $10, calculates the shortage as 48 artists, and shows the work.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the perfectly competitive wage would be $22 and/or does not explain that the wage would be determined by the intersection of the supply curve and the marginal revenue product curve.
The response states that the perfectly competitive wage would be $22 and explains that the wage would be determined by the intersection of the supply curve and the marginal revenue product curve.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that the firm should hire more artists and/or does not explain that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (9) is greater than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (4), or the firm can get more output for its money by hiring more workers and renting less capital, or
